I think younger people look at these and feel quizzical at best. It must be like looking at ancient ruins of collapsed civilizations–interesting but not particularly emotional and definitely not nostalgic. I bet Western kids who go to Asian countries where malls and large, vibrant market spaces still exist get some culture shock, and then mistakenly attribute the phenomenon as a uniquely non-Western invention. For you younger people to understand: most people in their late thirties and older see images of dead malls more nostalgically–more wistfully–as though revisiting a childhood home that has burned down or rotted. Basically a cured form of foie gras. Think pate, but without any herbs or spices. Difficult and tedious to make, but worth the effort.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18655037
They take the entire liver, season it with salt, pepper, sugar and a little brandy and then roll it into a tight log in cheesecloth and let it cure for a day or so. It's then poached, allowed to cure for another day, and then sliced into rounds. If you got it in a restaurant and didn't know what it was you'd probably think it was some kind of pate or mousse, but it wasn't ground up at all even though it essentially spreads like butter.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've mostly only encountered it in dried form, but I have made chili with it once. Cayenne is spicy enough that you will feel it burning your tongue. If you haven't tried it before, just one should be enough for a single pasta dish, two would be pushing it (and an excellent excuse to drink a lot of beer).

If you've used dried takanotsume you've had a milder (it tops out at 30000 scoville) version of the cayenne (it ranges from 30000 to 50000 scoville). You can reduce the heat level somewhat by removing the seeds and inner membrane.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18654237
One whole chilli is a reasonable amount for a dish, they vary though (even multiple chillies picked from the same plant), so there's no certain answer beyond your own taste. The heat is in the white pith ribs inside, which grow towards the stem end. You can cut the very tip off to taste what the chilli is like without heat, and try a slice from nearer the top to see what its maximum heat is like.

threads.sub: what's the point of buying cinammon in sticks like this?
threads.com: why not just buy the cinnamon already ground up for you?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18653230
thanks Dr Faggot

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Several reasons.
Firstly dried spice goes stale ten times faster than whole spice, grind whole spice and do a side-by-side, see for yourself.

Secondly you may not want the powder in your food, because it's bark and the texture is obvious. For example if you were glazing a pastry with cinnamon.

Third powdered spice is apt to burn and is more or less unusable both when flavoring sugar syrups or flavoring oil. The powder would stick dead and immediately burn.

This is also true of cassia and many other hard woody spices.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18653246
Cassia is far milder and less prone to bitterness, even when substituted with cinnamon in terms of flavor.

There are a number of dirty ways companies fool consumers who are not privy to the international standard quality rating scales used by producers and dealers

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18651723
Hash browns need a fuck ton of oil. Like WAY more than you think you need. That's why when you get them from a restaurant they're covered in grease. Also as the water from the potatoes evaporates its replaced with oil, so some of the oil actually absorbs up into the potato. It's also better to cook hash browns on medium-low heat for a longer time than on high heat for a short time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18651630
cook on a lower heat (like medium) so you can control the browning of the potatos, and make sure to move it around so you get even color
cook the bacon starting in a cold pan, or cook it in the oven to fully render the fat.
cooking things on a lower heat makes it a lot easier to control your food. and cooking bacon slow and at lower heat is key to making it not chewy.
